results.headline: Giants Die-Hard Takes One for the Team
results.summary_short: “Big Fan” is a spasmodically funny and bleak film about the love that speaks its name.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Fan

results.headline: Avast, Eco-Pirates, Here Be Whalers
results.summary_short: “At the Edge of the World” is an intrepid record of modern-day piracy and the high-stakes battle between commerce and ecological survival.
results.display_title: At the Edge of the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of At the Edge of the World

results.headline: Buried Heartaches Rise at a Quiet Family Reunion
results.summary_short: The Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda has a deceptively simple touch with the quiet, stirring film “Still Walking.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still Walking

results.headline: Embracing Life Under Scrutiny, Before the Dawn of Nonstop Tweets
results.summary_short: “We Live in Public” looks at one man’s experiments with issues of privacy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Live in Public

results.headline: The Cameras Zoom In on Fashion’s Empress
results.summary_short: “The September Issue” has little to say about fashion, the real ins and outs of publishing or the inner workings of the magazine’s meanie-in-chief, Anna Wintour.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The September Issue

results.headline: A Quiet Little Town With an Unsolved Murder and Greedy Developers
results.summary_short: The formidable talent and serious intention poured into Giancarlo Esposito’s “Gospel Hill” go only a tiny way toward enlivening an overpopulated film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gospel Hill

results.headline: What I Saw at the Countercultural Revolution
results.summary_short: “Taking Woodstock” is a gentle, meandering celebration of personal liberation at a moment when rigid social barriers were becoming more permeable.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taking Woodstock

results.headline: Airborne Stars of Extreme Sports Take Their Tricks to the 3-D Screen
results.summary_short: If you enjoy watching men soaring into the air on skateboards, snowboards and dirt bikes and then crashing, then you’ll like the movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of X Games 3D: The Movie

results.headline: A Dead Teenage Loser Improves in Grief’s Glow
results.summary_short: With a merciless acuity this nihilistic comedy ridicules collective grief and the news media’s cynical marketing of inspirational uplift after a death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of World's Greatest Dad

results.headline: A Young Artist’s Journey, This Time on Film
results.summary_short: “Passing Strange: The Movie” immerses the viewer at once in the story and the process of performance, emphasizing the play’s fidelity to emotional facts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passing Strange

results.headline: The Journalist Who Exchanged Her Typewriter for a Gun
results.summary_short: “The Baader Meinhof Complex” is a taut, unnerving, forcefully unromantic film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Baader Meinhof Complex

results.headline: 5 Stories, Pulled Out of a Box
results.summary_short: “Shorts” surges forward and rewinds, pauses and skips around as if controlled by a remote-wielding toddler.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shorts

results.headline: Jobless, but Charming
results.summary_short: When someone as fetching as Alexis Bledel can’t get a job — or a decent movie role — then we are officially in the depths of economic recession.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Post Grad

results.headline: Hitting the Highway to Find a New Husband
results.summary_short: “My One and Only” is a good-natured screwball road film set in 1953.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My One and Only

results.headline: Tarantino Avengers in Nazi Movieland
results.summary_short: “Inglourious Basterds” is simply another testament to Quentin Tarantino’s movie love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inglourious Basterds

results.headline: Rage, Forgiveness and Points in Between
results.summary_short: “Five Minutes of Heaven” is a feature-length talkathon built on a sketchy premise and strong star turns from Liam Neeson and James Nesbitt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Five Minutes of Heaven

results.headline: Barely Juggling Multiple Lives
results.summary_short: “Fifty Dead Men Walking,” a streamlined, adrenalized thriller that is not as deep as it would like to appear, treads a retrospective political tightrope.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fifty Dead Men Walking

results.headline: He Once Was Clueless, but Then He Evolved
results.summary_short: “Confessions of a Ex-Doofus-Itchy Footed Mutha” is probably Melvin Van Peebles’s most personal film since “Sweet Sweetback’s Baad Asssss Song,” which is a mixed blessing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confessionsofa Ex-Doofus-ItchyFooted Mutha

results.headline: Telenovela Wars
results.summary_short: With a surrogate for every demographic and a heroine for every taste, “Casi Divas” jiggles and jokes its way around as many Mexican box-office bases as possible.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Casi Divas

results.headline: The Admen of the ’70s: Bohemians Who Surf
results.summary_short: The world may be going “Mad Men,” but Doug Pray’s documentary “Art & Copy” presents a very different picture of the advertising industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Art & Copy
